definitions: become firm or solid by forming a semi-solid jelly-like substance
come together and function harmoniously as a team or unified group
examples: The mixture will gel after cooling for two hours
Allow the dessert to gel completely before serving
The team finally gelled after several months of working together
Their creative ideas began to gel into a coherent plan

definitions: surgically remove the testicles of a male animal to prevent reproduction
examples: The farmer decided to geld the young stallion last spring
Many horse owners geld their colts before they turn two

definitions: make a broad statement or conclusion based on specific examples or limited evidence
extend or apply a principle or conclusion more widely beyond specific instances
examples: You shouldn't generalize about people based on stereotypes
Scientists generalize their findings from controlled experiments carefully
The theory generalizes well to other similar situations
We can generalize this approach to solve related problems

definitions: produce or create something through a process or as a result of actions
produce electrical power or energy through mechanical or chemical processes
examples: The new marketing campaign generated significant interest from customers
Their research generated valuable insights into consumer behavior
The wind turbines generate enough electricity for the entire town
Solar panels generate clean energy from sunlight throughout the day

definitions: make or become mild, soft, or less harsh in manner or effect
handle or treat something or someone with careful, tender movements
examples: The trainer worked to gentle the frightened horse over time
Years of experience had gentled his previously harsh demeanor
She gentled the crying baby with soft words and rocking
You need to gentle the dough when kneading it

definitions: begin to grow or sprout from a seed or spore into a plant
begin to develop or come into existence gradually over time
examples: The seeds will germinate within seven to ten days
Most vegetable seeds germinate best in warm, moist soil
The idea for the novel germinated during her travels abroad
Plans for the project had been germinating for several months

definitions: make movements with hands or body to express ideas or feelings
indicate or direct attention to something through physical movements or actions
examples: She gestured wildly while explaining the complicated story to us
The conductor gestured for the orchestra to begin playing softly
He gestured toward the door to indicate we should leave
The host gestured to the empty chair beside her

definitions: obtain, receive, or come to have something through effort or chance
come to be in a particular state or condition gradually
come to understand or grasp the meaning of something mentally
arrive at or reach a particular place or destination
examples: I need to get groceries from the store today
She got a promotion after working hard all year
The weather is getting colder as winter approaches quickly
He's getting better at playing piano with daily practice
I finally get what you're trying to explain to me
Do you get the joke everyone is laughing about?
We should get home before the storm arrives tonight
What time did you get to the office today?

definitions: suddenly stop all communication with someone without explanation or warning
write material that will be officially credited to another person
follow or shadow someone secretly and quietly like a ghost
examples: He ghosted her after three dates without any explanation
Many people ghost their matches on dating apps nowadays
She ghosts speeches for several prominent political figures regularly
The celebrity hired someone to ghost his autobiography last year
The detective ghosted the suspect through the crowded marketplace silently
Security personnel ghosted the diplomat throughout her visit yesterday

definitions: give something to someone as a present without expecting payment
endow someone with a natural ability or talent from birth
examples: She decided to gift her grandmother's jewelry to her daughter
They gifted the newlyweds a beautiful set of china plates
Nature gifted him with an extraordinary singing voice from birth
She was gifted with the ability to learn languages easily

definitions: transfer the possession or ownership of something to someone else
provide or supply something needed or requested to someone
yield, produce, or emit something as a result or output
perform or carry out a specified action or gesture
examples: Please give me the book when you're finished reading
She gave her old clothes to charity last weekend
The teacher gives homework assignments every Friday afternoon
This hotel gives excellent service to all its guests
The lemon tree gives fruit twice a year reliably
The investment will give good returns over time
She gave a brilliant speech at the conference yesterday
He gave her a warm smile across the room

definitions: make someone feel happy, joyful, or pleased about something
examples: The news of her recovery gladdened everyone's hearts tremendously
It gladdens me to see the children playing happily

definitions: take a quick or brief look at something or someone
hit something at an angle and bounce off or slide past
examples: She glanced at her watch to check the time
He glanced around the room looking for familiar faces
The bullet glanced off the metal shield harmlessly yesterday
The ball glanced off the goalpost into the net

definitions: stare at someone or something with an angry or fierce expression
shine with a strong, harsh, dazzling light that hurts eyes
examples: She glared at him when he interrupted her presentation
The teacher glared at the students who were talking
The sun glared down on the desert sand mercilessly
Headlights glared through the fog on the dark highway

definitions: cover or coat something with a smooth, shiny liquid coating
become glassy, dull, or unfocused in appearance, especially eyes
fit glass into windows or other openings in buildings
examples: The baker glazed the donuts with sweet chocolate icing
She glazed the ceramic pottery before firing it again
His eyes glazed over during the long, boring lecture
Her expression glazed with exhaustion after the night shift
They need to glaze the new windows before winter arrives
The contractor will glaze the greenhouse panels next week

definitions: shine brightly with reflected light, especially intermittently or briefly
appear or be visible briefly or partially through something
examples: The polished silver gleamed in the candlelight beautifully
Her eyes gleamed with excitement at the news
A solution gleamed through the complicated problem we faced
Hope gleamed faintly in the darkness of despair

definitions: extract or gather information, facts, or materials bit by bit
gather grain or other produce left behind after the main harvest
examples: She gleaned important details from various research sources carefully
Reporters gleaned information from multiple witnesses at the scene
Poor farmers would glean the fields after the harvest
Workers gleaned the remaining wheat from the harvested fields

definitions: move smoothly and continuously along, as if without effort
fly through air without engine power using air currents
examples: The dancers glided gracefully across the polished ballroom floor
The boat glided silently through the calm morning water
The eagle glided on thermal currents high above mountains
The pilot glided the plane safely to the runway

definitions: shine faintly with a wavering or flickering unsteady light
appear or occur briefly and faintly as a slight indication
examples: Stars glimmered faintly in the cloudy night sky above
The candle glimmered weakly in the drafty old room
A glimmer of understanding finally appeared in his eyes
Hope glimmered briefly before fading away once more

definitions: see or perceive briefly or partially, often by chance
examples: I glimpsed a deer running through the forest yesterday
She glimpsed her reflection in the store window briefly

definitions: experience a sudden, temporary malfunction or irregularity in operation
examples: The computer system glitched during the important presentation yesterday
The video game glitches whenever too many players join

definitions: shine brightly with flashing or sparkling reflected light particles
examples: The diamond necklace glittered under the bright stage lights
Fresh snow glittered in the morning sunlight like crystals

definitions: describe or represent as admirable, especially unjustifiably or excessively
make something appear more glorious or splendid than it really is
examples: The movie glorifies violence instead of showing its consequences
Some history books glorify war heroes while ignoring civilian suffering
The article glorified his achievements beyond their actual significance
Artists often glorify nature in their romantic landscape paintings

definitions: take great pride or pleasure in something achieved or possessed
rejoice proudly or boast about something considered praiseworthy
examples: She glories in her children's academic achievements every year
The team gloried in their unexpected championship victory yesterday
He tends to glory in his wealth and expensive possessions
They gloried in their freedom after years of oppression

definitions: emit a steady light or heat without flame, often warmly colored
experience or show warm satisfaction, pride, or emotional warmth
examples: The embers glowed orange in the fireplace all night
The city lights glowed softly in the evening fog
She glowed with pride at her daughter's graduation ceremony
His face glowed with happiness when she said yes

definitions: fasten or join things together using adhesive substance or glue
fix or focus one's attention intensely on something without moving
examples: She carefully glued the broken vase pieces back together
You need to glue the edges before the adhesive dries
The children glued their eyes to the television screen
He remained glued to his computer screen all day

definitions: supply or fill to excess with more than is needed or can be handled
eat or consume something greedily or to excess
examples: The market is glutted with cheap imported electronics currently
Overproduction has glutted the oil market this year
He glutted himself on chocolate cake at the party
Don't glut yourself before the main course arrives tonight

definitions: provoke or annoy someone to stimulate action or reaction
drive cattle or animals forward using a pointed stick
examples: His constant criticism goaded her into proving him wrong
The coach goaded the team to perform beyond their limits
Farmers goaded the oxen forward with long wooden sticks
The herder goaded the cattle along the mountain path

definitions: play the sport of golf on a course with clubs and balls
examples: He golfs every Saturday morning at the country club
They golfed together in Scotland during their vacation trip

definitions: make a silly mistake or blunder through carelessness or inattention
spend time foolishly or aimlessly without accomplishing anything productive
examples: I really goofed when I sent that email to everyone
She goofed up the presentation by forgetting her notes
Stop goofing around and finish your homework assignment now
They goofed off all afternoon instead of studying together

definitions: search for information about something on the internet using a search engine
examples: I'll google the restaurant to find their menu online
She googled her symptoms before visiting the doctor yesterday

definitions: poke or pinch someone playfully, especially on the buttocks
give a sudden boost or increase to something's speed or power
examples: Someone goosed him as he walked through the crowd
The kids were goosing each other and laughing loudly
The pilot goosed the throttle to gain more altitude
Sales were goosed by the holiday promotional campaign significantly

definitions: pierce or wound with horns, tusks, or other sharp body parts
provide clothing with triangular pieces of fabric for shaping
examples: The bull gored the matador during the dangerous bullfight
The wild boar gored the hunter's leg with its tusks
The seamstress gored the skirt to create a fuller silhouette
She gored the dress panels for a more flattering fit

definitions: eat large amounts of food greedily and to excess
fill something completely or block it with excessive amounts
examples: They gorged themselves on pizza at the buffet restaurant
Don't gorge on snacks before dinner is served tonight
The drain was gorged with leaves after the storm
Traffic gorged the narrow streets during rush hour yesterday

definitions: engage in casual conversation about other people's private affairs or behavior
examples: The neighbors gossip about everyone on the street constantly
She gossiped with her friends during their lunch break

definitions: make a groove, hole, or indentation by scooping or digging forcefully
charge someone unfairly high prices, especially exploiting their need
examples: The vandals gouged deep scratches into the car's paint
She accidentally gouged a chunk from the wooden table
The hotel gouged tourists with extremely inflated prices yesterday
Some retailers gouge customers during natural disasters unfairly

definitions: conduct the policy and affairs of a state, organization, or people with authority
control, influence, or regulate behavior, actions, or processes
examples: The president governs the country according to constitutional law
The board governs the university with careful fiscal oversight
Physical laws govern the movement of celestial bodies precisely
Strict rules govern student conduct in the dormitories

definitions: seize suddenly and roughly with the hand or grasp quickly
attract or capture someone's attention or interest quickly and forcefully
examples: She grabbed her keys and rushed out the door
The thief grabbed the purse and ran down the street
The headline really grabbed my attention this morning immediately
This opening scene will grab the audience from the start

definitions: honor or favor an event or place with one's presence or participation
give elegance, beauty, or honor to something through presence or addition
examples: The celebrity graced the charity event with her presence
The Queen graced the ceremony with a brief appearance
Beautiful paintings grace the walls of the ancient palace
Her smile graced the cover of the fashion magazine

definitions: evaluate and assign a score or mark to academic work or performance
arrange things in groups according to quality, size, or other criteria
level or smooth a ground surface for construction or roadwork
examples: The teacher grades all essays over the weekend carefully
Professors grade exams based on established rubric criteria
Workers grade the fruit by size before packaging them
The company grades diamonds according to clarity and color
The crew will grade the road before laying new asphalt
They graded the land to prepare for building construction

definitions: successfully complete an academic degree or course of training
progress or change gradually through a series of stages or levels
mark an instrument or container with units of measurement
examples: She will graduate from medical school next spring semester
He graduated with honors from the prestigious university yesterday
The program graduates from basic to advanced skill levels
The colors graduate from light to dark across the canvas
The scientist graduated the cylinder for precise measurements carefully
They graduated the thermometer in both Celsius and Fahrenheit

definitions: transplant living tissue from one part to another surgically
insert a shoot or twig into another plant to form new growth
work hard, especially at manual or difficult labor persistently
examples: Surgeons grafted skin from his leg onto the burn
Doctors will graft bone tissue to repair the fracture
The gardener grafted rose stems onto stronger rootstock carefully
Farmers graft fruit tree branches to improve crop yields
He grafted all day in the hot sun yesterday
She's been grafting hard to support her family financially

definitions: perform ostentatiously to impress an audience or attract attention and applause
examples: The politician was grandstanding during the televised committee hearing
Stop grandstanding and focus on solving the actual problem

definitions: give or allow someone something formally, officially, or legally
admit that something is true or accept it as valid
examples: The committee granted her request for additional research funding
The court granted custody of the children to their mother
I grant that your argument has some merit here
She granted his point but disagreed with the conclusion

definitions: plot or trace data points on a graph to show relationships visually
examples: Students must graph the experimental results for their report
She graphed the company's sales data over five years

definitions: engage in close physical combat or wrestling with someone forcefully
struggle to deal with or understand a difficult problem or issue
examples: The wrestlers grappled on the mat for several minutes
Security guards grappled with the intruder until police arrived
Scientists grapple with the complexities of climate change daily
She's been grappling with this decision for weeks now

definitions: seize and hold something firmly with the hand or hands
understand or comprehend something fully, especially something complex
examples: She grasped the rope tightly as she climbed upward
The baby grasped her finger with his tiny hand
He finally grasped the concept after hours of study
Students struggle to grasp advanced mathematical theories quickly

definitions: reduce food to small shreds by rubbing against a rough surface
make an unpleasant rasping sound by rubbing surfaces together harshly
irritate or annoy someone persistently with something unpleasant
examples: She grated fresh parmesan cheese over the pasta dish
Grate the carrots finely for the salad recipe tomorrow
The metal gate grated against the concrete when opening
Chalk grated on the blackboard making everyone cringe yesterday
His constant complaining really grates on my nerves daily
That high-pitched voice grates after listening too long

definitions: move toward something under the influence of gravitational or other force
be naturally attracted to or tend to move toward something appealing
examples: Objects gravitate toward the earth's center due to gravity
Planets gravitate around the sun in elliptical orbits continuously
Young people gravitate toward cities for job opportunities naturally
She tends to gravitate toward creative and artistic people

definitions: become gray in color, especially hair turning gray with age
make something gray in color or cause it to lose brightness
examples: His hair is graying at the temples quite noticeably
The sky grayed as storm clouds gathered overhead quickly
Time has grayed the once vibrant curtains significantly
Pollution grays the buildings in the industrial district
